evaluators.xai package

Submodules

evaluators.xai.XAI module

class evaluators.xai.XAI.XAI(config, model, dataloader)

Bases: object

xai(threshold=0.5)
evaluators.xai.XAI.agg_y(y, mask=None, out_agg_dim=(2, 3), num_classes=-1, cross_agg=False, agg_dim_fn=<built-in method mean of type object>, agg_mask_fn=<built-in method mean of type object>)

This wrapper aggreagates an output tensor over out_agg_dim using agg_dim_fn. This makes it easier to attribute with respect to a single output scalar, as opposed to individual pixel output attribution.

Instead, if a mask is provided (not None), it uses this mask to aggregate over the classes, either by simple direct masking if cross_agg=False where the mask just selects some wanted pixels from each output class, or by generating all possible combinations of the output classes with the masking classes if cross_agg=True. In this last case, the new number of classes is the product of original_classes x aggregation_classes. Selected samples are then aggreated using agg_mask_fn

It also expands the output channel dimension if it has only a size of 1 and num_classes>1. E.g.: it expands from binary classification to 2-class multiclass output

Note: Output classes must be located in dimension 1 of y, and for masked aggregation, dimension 1 must have a size of 1

evaluators.xai.XAI.attribute(config, model, dataloader, num_classes, out_agg_dim, agg_mode, threshold, debug=False)

Attribute over an arbitrary amount of input and output dimensions From config, it uses the following information:

For XAI:

  • config[‘evaluation’][‘xai’][‘params’][‘out_agg_dim’]

  • config[‘evaluation’][‘xai’][‘params’][‘type’]

For adapt_variables:

  • config[‘data’][‘data_dim’]

  • config[‘arch’][‘input_model_dim’]

It returns dictionaries with a key for every attributed event, as well as x_shape and y_shape

evaluators.xai.XAI.event_at_all(arr, t)

Takes an arr of shape (*), and creates a new one of shape (t, *), where the original arr is repeated t times over t index 0

evaluators.xai.XAI.event_at_beginning(arr, t)

Takes an arr of shape (*), and creates a new one of shape (t, *), where the original arr is at the first position of the 0th dimension, and the rest of the elements are zero

evaluators.xai.XAI.event_at_end(arr, t)

Takes an arr of shape (*), and creates a new one of shape (t, *), where the original arr is at the last position of the 0th dimension, and the rest of the elements are zero

evaluators.xai.XAI.get_agg_mask(agg_mode, y, y_labels, sample, threshold, error_threshold=0.5)

Compute the aggregation mask according to the agg_mode, which must be one of: [“none”, “threshold[-full]”, “correctness[-full]”, “labels[-full]”, “custom[-full]”]

evaluators.xai.XAI.get_multiindex_df(data, rows, columns, row_names=None, column_names=None, default_name='values')

Builds a multiindex + multicolumn pandas dataframe

Parameters:

  • data (numpy array with a shape that is consistent with the rows + columns provided) –

  • rows (a list of lists that will be used to build a MultiIndex, optionally empty list) –

  • columns (a list of lists that will be used to build a MultiIndex, optionally empty list) –

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

evaluators.xai.XAI.plot_attributions_1d(attributions: ndarray, inputs: ndarray, labels: ndarray, predictions: ndarray, feature_names: List[str], class_names: List[str], plot_classes_predictions: List[str] | None = None, plot_classes_attributions: List[str] | None = None, figsize: Tuple[float] = (10, 10), timesteps: ndarray | None = None, timestep: int | None = None, color_list=['tab:blue', 'tab:orange', 'tab:green', 'tab:red', 'tab:purple', 'tab:brown', 'tab:pink', 'tab:gray', 'tab:olive', 'tab:cyan'], title: str | None = None, outlier_perc: float = 2.0, margin_perc: float = 25.0, alpha: float = 0.8, attr_factor: float = 0.5, attr_baseline: str = 'middle', kind: str = 'stacked', names_position: str = 'left', label_fontsize: float = 8, is_classification: bool = True, **kwargs)

Plot 1D attributions (e.g. of a inputs) given an output timestep If you want to see absolute attributions, just do np.abs(attributions) yourself Shapes:

  • attributions: (out t, out classes, in t, in features)

  • inputs: (in t, in features)

  • labels: (out t, [out classes]) out classes is optional

  • predictions: (out t, out classes)

evaluators.xai.XAI.plot_attributions_nd(data, x_shape, y_shape, feature_names, class_names, figsize=(20, 10))

Plots avarage attributions over all dimensions except for output classes and input features It should work for any model
